author: schittli
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Good morning

it's great to have many PowerShell users - it's a great 'tool', thanks a lot for your great work!

### … but it's **very** annoying, that all those PowerShell users get this notification:
```
   A new PowerShell stable release is available: …
   Upgrade now, or check out the release page at:
   https://aka.ms/PowerShell-Release?tag=…
```

### The problem is, that most Users will start this process:
1. _"A new release? - great!"_
2. But: _"How can I upgrade PowerShell??"_
3. _"… ok, I'll upgrade it anytime later, I don't have time to ask google"_

### Therefore: please tell how PowerShell can be upgraded in the upgrade notification!

Something like this:
```
   A new PowerShell stable release is available: …
   Start upgrade by calling: …
   The Release Notes: https://aka.ms/PowerShell-Release?tag=…
```

Thanks a lot, kind regards,
Thomas

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It is not clear that you ask. The link in the notice open a page where you can download PowerShell distributive from.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
As @iSazonov points out, that link takes you to the downloads page (scroll past the release notes) for the updated version of PowerShell.  However, there are a number of ways PowerShell could be installed.  So the upgrade process isn't really a single upgrade process as it depends on how you installed PowerShell: direct MSI download, Windows Store, winget, Chocolatey, dotnet global tool, apt, yum, snap, homebrew, etc.  

Related to #8663

comments.author: ap-waaijenberg
comments.body:
The given PowerShell-Release page is quite confusing. I've eventually found the (huge) table of links to download the many version of installers somewhere in the middle. 
I would expect to run the command "upgrade" and the smart software that knows I need an upgrade, knows the version I am running, and knows where to find the new stuff just ask if I want Latest, Stable or Preview and start the download itself. That would have been neat.
Why not dream that it tells me "there is a new stable version X.Y.Z available, do you want to install it [Y/N]?"?

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body:
> How can I upgrade??

You have two main options.
If you have the ```Install-PowerShell.ps1``` script (you can find it here in this repo), just run it - the script downloads and runs the latest MSI. Note when you run it, you have the option of updating via MS Update (ensure it's checked).
If you have enabled updating via MU, then can just wait. It takes a couple of weeks after release to GitHub before MSFT can get it over to MU. I am not sure WHY it takes so long, but it does work.
